results.headline: Review: In ‘The Lego Batman Movie,’ Toys and Heroes, What’s Not to Like?
results.summary_short: Warner Bros. offers amusement at its own expense and Will Arnett gives great voice to Gotham’s brooder, but this new movie is still a commercial.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lego Batman Movie

results.headline: Review: In ‘Rings,’ Best Not Go to the Videotape
results.summary_short: The latest in a horror franchise that began in Japan, this film fills in the back story of Samara, the girl who kills via VCR.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rings

results.headline: Review: ‘Chapter & Verse’ Tells of Prison and Redemption
results.summary_short: This film from Jamal Joseph and Daniel Beaty centers on the struggles of an ex-con re-entering society.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chapter & Verse

results.headline: Review: ‘I Am Not Your Negro’ Will Make You Rethink Race
results.summary_short: Raoul Peck’s documentary is an important introduction to James Baldwin’s work and an advanced seminar in racial politics.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Not Your Negro

results.headline: Review: ‘Sophie and the Rising Sun’ Has Forbidden Love in a Foreboding Time
results.summary_short: The movie, set in 1941 and based on a novel by Augusta Trobaugh, finds a white woman and an Asian man falling in love, hindered by small-town prejudice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sophie and the Rising Sun

results.headline: Review: ‘This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous,’ a Self-Made Cover Girl
results.summary_short: Barbara Kopple’s film documents how Gigi Gorgeous, formerly Gregory Allan Lazzarato, took control of her transgender destiny with the support of her family.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous

results.headline: Review: In ‘Dark Night,’ Another Movie Theater, Another Shooting
results.summary_short: This fictional film by Tim Sutton was inspired by the massacre in 2012 at a showing of the film “The Dark Night Rises” in an Aurora, Colo., theater.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Night

results.headline: Review: ‘Eloise’ Has the Usual Haunted-Hospital Clichés
results.summary_short: Robert Legato’s horror movie is “a strange mix of the recycled and the surreal,” Jeannette Catsoulis writes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eloise

results.headline: Review: In ‘A Good American,’ Examining Sept. 11 and Data Collection
results.summary_short: Friedrich Moser’s documentary employs re-enactments, moving graphics and a Philip Glass-like score.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Good American

results.headline: Review: ‘Growing Up Smith’ Plants a Boy From India in 1979 America
results.summary_short: This gentle coming-of-age film centers on a youngster caught between two cultures and struggling to adapt in suburbia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Growing Up Smith

results.headline: Review: ‘Oklahoma City’ Recalls a Chilling Attack With Lessons for Today
results.summary_short: The film, directed by Barak Goodman, makes the unsettling case that Timothy McVeigh’s ideology was not isolated.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oklahoma City

results.headline: Review: ‘The Space Between Us,’ the Story of a Boy Who Fell to Earth
results.summary_short: Peter Chelsom’s movie concerns a young human (Asa Butterfield), raised in isolation on Mars, who visits Earth and a video-chat pal (Britt Robertson).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Space Between Us

results.headline: Review: ‘War on Everyone’ Is Missing Some Crucial Components
results.summary_short: The latest film from the writer and director John Michael McDonagh stars Alexander Skarsgard and Michael Peña as detectives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War on Everyone

results.headline: Review: ‘Youth in Oregon’ Takes a Family on a Contentious Ride
results.summary_short: A retiree who is unwilling to undergo further treatment for a heart condition just wants to die in peace, in Oregon. His family has issues with that.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Youth in Oregon

results.headline: Review: Robert De Niro as ‘The Comedian,’ a Has-Been Seeking a Comeback
results.summary_short: Joined by a cast that includes Edie Falco and Harvey Keitel, Mr. De Niro plays an insult comic in a film that, like its jokes, lacks zing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Comedian

results.headline: Review: ‘Mr. Gaga’ Doesn’t Sing but Has His Own (Dance) Language
results.summary_short: Tomer Heymann’s documentary on the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin is a scattered and somewhat confused film about an intriguing and complicated man.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Gaga

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Lure,’ Two Mermaids Walk Into a Strip Club (Things Get Weirder)
results.summary_short: Agnieszka Smoczynska’s first feature is a genre-bending tale that swerves from parody to fairy tale to gleeful gore, with camp decadence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lure

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Salesman,’ Scenes From a Marriage in Tehran
results.summary_short: The ghost of Willy Loman hovers over this film from Asghar Farhadi, but it seems occupied with its own dramatic issues, our critic writes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Salesman

results.headline: Review: In ‘Behemoth,’ the Horrors of Economic Progress
results.summary_short: This documentary from Zhao Liang is a feat of pictorial storytelling, where iron and coal workers are shown as cogs of the monster of China’s industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Behemoth

results.headline: Review: Shah Rukh Khan as ‘Raees,’ a Villain but Still a Do-Gooder
results.summary_short: The “king of Bollywood” rarely plays the bad guy, but in this film he’s a criminal who’s also fighting corruption in 1980s and ’90s India.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Raees
